awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Technology Pathway Program in Data Technology and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is developing an interdisciplinary technology pathway program (TPP) in data technology and applications for behavioral, social, and health science students at two California State Universities. It consists of four technical courses covering Python programming, data structures and algorithms, data technology, and an interdisciplinary senior project (or database). It will be offered as a minor degree program as part of bachelor's degree programs, or as a certificate program. The TPP program will use evidence-based teaching practices that encompass effective pedagogy as well as learning communities and faculty professional development. The program will use contextualized problem-based pedagogy in which students acquire key technical knowledge and skills by solving real-world problems. Each cohort of participating students will be formed into a learning community that will include professors and industry professionals in Silicon Valley for student support and role-modeling. The engineering and computing faculty who will teach the students in this program will engage in professional development in order to learn pedagogical approaches that have been shown effective for the diverse students in the social, behavioral, and health sciences. These faculty have agreed to participate in a Faculty Learning Community throughout the academic year and a summer Technology Pathway Summer Institute.  

The project is expected to generate research contributions towards the development of a technical education program for a diverse group of students and the creation of a sustainable interdisciplinary program that crosses internal organizational boundaries and links to external sponsors. If this project succeeds, it will very likely spur other campuses to develop similar programs through faculty development and dissemination plans. The ongoing evaluation of the propagation process and its outcomes will reveal valuable lessons for launching such interdisciplinary initiatives. One of the participating institutions is a minority serving institution.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant, A Technology Pathway Program (TPP) in Data Technology and Applications, has supported the development of the Applied Computing for Behavioral and Social Sciences (ACBSS) minor degree at San Jose State University (SJSU). The minor targets non-STEM behavioral and social sciences (BSS) students and was created in Fall 2017. It consists of four new interdisciplinary computing courses designed to be taken over a two-year period, covering subjects such as Python, R, data structures, database, algorithms, and culminating projects.  As of spring 2020, 44 students have completed the minor, 50% of whom are female and 36% are URM (underrepresented minority groups that include African American, Latinx, Pacific Islander, and American Indian) students.  In AY 2019-2020, 195 students were enrolled across all four courses, reflecting increasing interest in the degree. A survey administered to its graduates indicated that 87% of them planned to use their minor degree to pursue careers in the digital workplace. The success of the program is due to (1) a curriculum that focuses on problem-based learning with BSS applications, (2) the inclusion of career exploration activities and industry engagement in curricular and co-curricular programs, (3) the engagement of BSS faculty in recruiting BSS students and teaching ACBSS courses, along with computing faculty, and (4) an ongoing interdisciplinary faculty development program that includes a faculty learning community and an annual Interdisciplinary Computing Summer Institute (ICSI).  As a result of this NSF award, five papers were published and presented at conferences, and two more publications are being prepared.

The Interdisciplinary Computing Summer Institute aims to help faculty from different disciplines and campuses achieve success in providing diverse, non-CS students with computing skills needed for the workplace. To this end, it has brought together interdisciplinary computing employers and faculty to share insights and build connections each summer for the past five years.

Intellectual Merit: This research demonstrates that ACBSS students respond positively to contextualized problem-based learning and supportive environments by showing promising shifts in their confidence, attitudes, and career goals. The successful development of a new interdisciplinary degree requires regular engagements of faculty with broad experience in administration, teaching, faculty development, and educational research.

Broader Impacts: The TPP project has demonstrated a promising model for providing computing education to non-STEM students, thus making computing education more accessible to a broader segment of college students including female and URM students. Graduates from interdisciplinary computing programs are more productive contributors to the expanding digital economy, thereby enhancing American competitiveness and generating broader prosperity across boundaries of gender, ethnicity, and socio-economic status. To propagate this model more broadly, a university-industry interdisciplinary computing alliance was created. The alliance consists of industry partners and six major public universities in California: UC Berkeley, San Francisco State University, SJSU, UC Davis, UC Riverside, and California Polytechnic University, San Luis Obispo.  The annual summer ICSI provides a platform for faculty from these campuses and employers to collaborate on developing educational and career pathways for interdisciplinary computing students.

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2022
Modified by: Belle Wei
